0.author: SCMtnGuy
0.body:
Nope. Some nucleosynthesis (formation of atomic nuclei) did occur in the big bang, but only light elements, so hydrogen, helium, plus a little lithium and trace of beryllium were formed initially.

Once rapid initial expansion was finished and gravity could take over, stars began to form, and this is where many more elements else came from. Stars can create elements up to iron, depending on the size of the star and its age. Up to that point, adding to the size of an atomic nucleus increases the stability, which means it releases energy during the process. Beyond iron, formation of heavier elements absorbs energy instead of releasing it, so some of these elements form during the death of a small to medium star resulting in a supernova. That process only yields up to rubidium since it's not energetic enough and the resulting neutron capture is relatively slow. For really heavy elements, like gold, platinum, and uranium, you need really energetic events,  things like collisions with neutron stars. The basic mechanism for all the heavier than iron elements is neutron capture followed by conversion of a neutron to a proton by β- decay, but the range of elements that can be formed is limited by the energy of the neutrons involved. 

Our star is a third generation star, which is why the nebula it formed from had enough silicon, oxygen, carbon, nitrogen, etc., to have planets and life. Without these elements, all derived from the ashes of earlier stars and various cataclysmic events, it would be a pretty boring place.

0.author: beans3710
0.body: Yes, that's the "as a result of", part (ie, created by the stars). I was just avoiding the details. The point being, none of the elements were created on earth, which was the implication of the OP.

0.author: SCMtnGuy
0.body: There absolutely are elements created on Earth, though. Most of our radon, for example, formed right here. Granted, it's nothing unique about the Earth environment that makes this happen, it's a just from the decay of radium. But, regardless, the elemental composition of Earth has changed from its initial accretion. Although, I suppose if you include humans as something unique about the environmental conditions on Earth, then there are new elements that formed here via processes not known to occur anywhere else.

0.author: beans3710
0.body: Ok, other than through radioactive decay of elements created in the stars or in reactors. I was really just saying that the deuterium from the original post didn't likely come from earth.

0.author: SCMtnGuy
0.body: Some could be made here. The cross section for capture of thermal neutrons by protonium is 0.33 barns, so if you had brine circulating through mineral formations containing a lot of uranium or thorium, some deuterium formation would be expected. But, in the grand scheme of things, that's not much compared to how much deuterium the planet got just from the start. I'd expect it to be insignificant in comparison, and I have no idea how you'd tell new deuterium from ancient deuterium since it's a stable isotope.

5.author: Tiny_Fractures
5.body:
All of that is correct. However, nihilism blossoms out of relativism. Nothing can be known because there is no solid position to know it from.

Yet, here we are doing it. You said it yourself, you cannot know but yet here you are talking to me knowing. And I, you. Why are we doing it? Because in this instant we are forced to. Not forced as in physically. Or forced as in you or I can walk away from this conversation. But forced as in the undefined future (which itself arguably doesn't exist (depending on how you define "exist") that was a future is now here and we're in it...me talking to you and you talking to me. And we can choose to nihilistically not talk because nothing comes of it and we may not even be real and all that. Or, we can polarize ourselves into a state...we can choose to believe a lie insomuch as it makes us real (within the lie), and then choose to talk to each other in that lie.

5.author: VonnegutGNU
5.body:
You inherently can't know things - nihilism.

There isn't an inherently preferred frame of reference- relativism.

Two completely separate ideas. The first is about the inability to know truth, the second is about the inexistence of an absolute truth. Neither requires the other.

5.author: Tiny_Fractures
5.body:
Requires being the operative word. I never said they were the same idea. Nor than one is needed for the other. I said one flows into another (caveat that one does so if taking that perspective). You can get to nihilism several ways. 

You can also choose to hold nihilism standalone...in the same way you could say I am not you. But that draws us into the overall reason we're in this conversation. If you are doing so to protect an idea of nihilism in your head...its true polarizing it as far as possible from other ideas will do that. But also if thats the goal, I dont see why the idea needs to be defended. 

If on the other hand you're open to examining the relationships nihilism has to other ideas, then that necessitates depolarizing it. Which inherently makes it vulnerable.

5.author: VonnegutGNU
5.body:
"that necessitates depolarizing it. Which inherently makes it vulnerable."

Do you not feel like you're spewing verbiage akin to a new age mystic? 

Nihilism holds without relativity. In a world of only one operant, without any other possible alternative views, nihilism still holds. Moral relativism can be said to flow from nihilism, but only insomuch as "no possible morality" means "no absolute morality".

5.author: Tiny_Fractures
5.body:
> Do you not feel like you're spewing verbiage akin to a new age mystic?

I'm a pretty logical dude. A physicist by trade. What I've said so far makes a ton of sense. I can understand it being a little complicated. 

> Nihilism holds without relativity

Everything is capable of holding without anything else. It is the "in itself"-ness Hegel talks about. But the fact of the matter is (coming full circle again) things are "forced" by time, space, etc to be in relation to one another. So even though yes...

> "no possible morality" means "no absolute morality"

In the relation we choose A morality or A perspective or A view, knowing (or being ignorant that) its a lie. And its not that the choice, as nihilism would say, is meaningful or right or logical or however you want to frame it that I'm making conversation about. Its not *what* we choose. But simply the essential fact *that* we choose. Because we have to. It is forced upon us.

5.author: VonnegutGNU
5.body:
Your reasoning for "I'm a pretty logical dude" could have just as easily come from Bobby Fischer, Ted Kaczynski, or Nikola Tesla.

What is forced upon us, within the framework of nihilism? There is nothing to speak of, except the entity that doubts, and even that comes with caveats.

That we "choose" is an entirely separate sector of philosophizing, from which I have also never heard anything convincing from, aside from "There is no such thing as choice".

5.body:

I dunno. But it seems you're getting a little worked up. So I'll leave you to your "peace".

10.body:
So, quick question. While I do roughly agree with what your saying; I am questioning your perspective.

Now I'd imagine you'd say the same for Russia, Nazi/Eastern Germany, etc. 

What if I gave you some sources on how American presidents have been doing as such since the 40s. Would you feel the same way towards our elected officials?

10.author: galahad423
10.body:
First, you don’t need to provide them. I’m well aware. But I appreciate your smug condescension! I was a history teacher and literally taught US social and political history, including all the ways our government has and continues to fuck up. 

To your point; 

This is sort of a complicated question in legal terms. 

By all means take them to court for any *extrajudicial* crimes they’ve committed.

I’ll point out the US government is objectively more legitimate than the East German one though, and as a result it’s harder to prosecute public officials when they act within the scope of their legal authority, since they’re protected by sovereign immunity. I’m not necessarily saying don’t try, but you’ll almost certainly lose the case on those grounds alone. This defense doesn’t really apply in Honecker’s case given he wasn’t elected. He was essentially a soviet puppet. We’re not talking about the leader of a state where rights like freedom of speech, thought, or the press aren’t always *respected,* in East Germany they **didn’t legally exist.** This guy was head of a government which literally shot its own citizens for trying to leave (AND HE’S THE ONE WHO HAD THE IDEA). While I’ll concede US elections aren’t necessarily free or fair (especially where minority rights are concerned historically up to and including present day) there’s still a vast distinction between an appointed de-facto dictator of a police state and an at-least sort-of-legitimately elected leader bound by due process and law. If you can prove any US official was acting beyond their legitimate authority when someone suffers a violation of their civil rights, they can (and should!) be prosecuted. I’d also suggest that while you’d have a stronger case for prosecuting US presidents the further back you go, certainly in the aftermath of the Civil Rights Act your case gets weaker and weaker, as more and more protections against state-sponsored and codified discrimination come online.

Honecker was also being prosecuted for the extrajudicial crimes perpetrated by the state, especially the Stasi, when he was in charge (and as a result he bears final responsibility). I’d encourage you to look into their activities, and ask whether there’s any true American parallels. Again, I’ll concede that US law enforcement has been incredibly selective with its enforcement of law against citizens (again targeting minorities), including through extrajudicial killings, especially (but not exclusively) in the days before civil rights (and id support prosecution in **any and all** of those instances!). Again, there are limited parallels between racist cops abusing black people and the massive surveillance apparatuses of the CIA and FBI, and the broad activities of Stasi, but these don’t really compare in scale or in their institutionalization of violence with what the stasi were up to. Its comparing grapes to watermelons. They might both be fruits and shaped similarly, but there’s a BIG difference. Many of those activities perpetrated by the CIA/FBI/Police also were, even at the time, still technically *illegal*, even if those laws weren’t respected or properly enforced (they should have been). In *theory* in the US, even in the 1960s, you could prevail on an excessive force lawsuit against US police. Even trying to *file* that sort of thing in Honecker’s East germany would probably get you thrown into a cell and beaten more, if not disappeared. To reiterate, if you can prove any US official is **directly culpable** for clear violations of civil rights and US law, lock em up!

I’ll also point out that because the US has certain protections of civil rights in place, this gives top officials some protection from culpability for the crimes their lower officers might inflict when those lower ranking individuals violate the law. To give you an example, you’d have a hard time prosecuting Trump for the killing of Eric Garner or George Floyd, even if, as the head of government, he bears final responsibility for his governments actions because those killings were *violations* of US law. You can prosecute those cops, but their bosses (and their boss’ bosses, all the way up to the President) will just claim that they certainly didn’t endorse and aren’t responsible for the actions of those individuals and that those actions violated departmental policy/state/federal law, and this is typically enough to secure them from liability (assuming the violation actually *was* illegal or against policy. If not, they’re still likely on the hook). At a certain point, the government can say “that wasn’t supposed to happen and it’s not legal, so it’s not our fault one guy broke the law and happens to work for us. We told him not to do it. It’s (only) his fault. ” 

I’ll also concede the US has done atrocious things to human beings all over the world, but there’s (legally speaking) a huge difference in domestically prosecuting a state leader for what their dictatorship did to their own citizens as opposed to domestically prosecuting a democratically elected leader for the military’s war crimes abroad. Again, not denying that going back to at least Korea, US leaders have been, at least in part, legally culpable for war crimes. But that’s a matter for an international court and international law (which the Us will never submit to and isn’t formally governed by). It’s not the same as the people of a country prosecuting their own leader for what his government did to its own people, in violation of its own national laws. So again, prove to me any US official is as legally culpable for the actions of their lower officials or has directly acted in ways which violate US law and civil rights, and I’m all for prosecuting everyone responsible! No one should be above the law.

12.author: V6Ga
12.body:
But Nyan is also the word for cat, because it is.

Generally used as a compound eg. Nyan-ko, the same way a Dog is often not an Inu but Wan-chan, or a bicycle is not Jitensha but Chalinko. Pop culture proof: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Onyanko_Club the Kitty club, not the meowing club.

We abbreviate words in English as a regular move. Puppy becomes Pup, Bicycle becomes bike. In Japanese it is more regular to make a new word from its onomatapoeia noise, and add a bit to the end.

(This ignores the impossible to easily explain abbreviation rules that make high school into Koko, or the UN into Kokuren, but those are more like acronyms.)

17.author: SokoJojo
17.body:
My thoughts are that we need to table the discussion because I can't make arguments without posting the complete series of work. 

If you were to read my axiom and follow the logical construction it would read like it was written from the ground up. In theory, it could have be written that way, but in practice it was actually written from the top down after I picked up on something that was deeper than what I understood. I had figured out that if I could get data to track into cohesive patterns across the system (in this case the system being the human brain), I could guarantee fidelity in the concepts I was putting together. This would not guarantee everything was altogether perfect (small nuances can still exist) nor did it mean it would be complete, but it meant that for what I had there was some strong corresponding component of truth to the part the reconciled the data.

It looks like this:

change the core concepts -> change the pattern of data predicted by these concepts to exist -> shift the pattern of present off its axis of symmetry with the *actual* pattern of data that does exist -> lose the balance of harmony that I had achieved. 

On this, the epistemology is much stronger than if it were isolated to itself because it's being packaged with a real world demonstration of what this looks like in terms of solving out this great brain mystery of sleep. Hence, it's merit is demonstrable. 


Where I am now is that I have the paper mostly written, I'm just tinkering with writing in the introduction -- not changing concepts at this point because everything works fine. The thing is I've just never actually published a paper before, and it's a lot of work to submit because it's introducing some very big ideas that people are not accustomed to, and the entire thing is overwhelmingly. My theories are right, but the fear is if I don't say things perfectly right away they may get prematurely dismissed before having the chance to make the proper arguments and showcase what these concepts to do, and it feels paralyzing sometimes trying to get everything perfect.

17.author: SokoJojo
17.body:
Hey so I needed to go back and erase the comments because I got too specific in some of my ideas and I don't want things permanent linked to my account on here. I hope you don't take that personally or anything because it has nothing to do with you. Usually when I comment on science on here it's vague enough that it doesn't matter, but I can't be both vague and specific simultaneously.

I actually really value our correspondence on here, I've never had a chance to communicate my ideas to someone else because I'm no longer in the proper environment for it and it makes it hard writing out a paper when you have no idea how the audience is going to be able to receive the idea you are trying to communicate.

You are actually right not to accept the claims I am making beyond acknowledging partial aspects because they are making very strong claims and reaching fairly revolutionary conclusions while providing only partial arguments and continuing to stay relatively vague. This is the reached conundrum in our discussion though, because while these arguments can be continued with specifically detailed logical continuations to validate them, it would mean turnover detailed core aspects of my work before submitting the paper. If you're not familiar with neuroscience and biochemistry, it also makes it harder to demonstrate how this epistemology isn't just a theoretical description but translates quite spectacular in terms of it's real world application.

It looks like this packaged together:

1. My field-specific work in brain sciences demonstrates that by focusing on tracking information into patterns across the system it guarantees reality (this isn't just a claim, but because it works it creates a situation where the physical data is overwhelmingly consistent and anyone can see that)

2. My epistemology work (which we are discussing) is essentially the result of me understanding that this *does* work (you do not need to understand why it works to see that it does) and then over serious reflection and quite a bit of time I eventually figured out the basis for why this works. Because it's mathematically, when it's correctly explained it's validity because self-evident in the context of what it is claiming. This comes back to the axiom I wrote out before.

As you can see, however, this packaging together is a much stronger product than either of the two things isolated to themselves. While each could stand on their own in theory, when package together it becomes especially difficult to deny because each validates the other.

18.author: jimmy9800
18.body:
Im glad yours aren't too bad. I wouldn't mind the auras so much if the headache was nicer. I get [cluster headaches](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cluster_headache) after the auras finish for me if I just power through the auras, and will go to the hospital for monitoring if I know one is coming. They are terrifying. I'd rather have kidney stones every week than go through that.

My triggers are kind of odd, and the whole thing is related to a tbi I had ice skating when i was 7. Jumping (including running, which sucks), dark chocolate, violent vomiting, and pulling all nighters are all pretty reliable at giving me a migrane. I still get the odd one for no reason once a year or so, but I can make myself have one if I jump rope for 5 minutes. Comes in handy for fmri imaging, as long as they have sumatriptan to stop it before it gets bad.

18.author: thatsalotofcats
18.body: Oh man that’s terrible!! I’m sorry yours are so terrible. I wish they could figure out how to stop them forever.

18.author: jimmy9800
18.body:
Thanks for the camaraderie! Good news is i kind of have stopped the worst of it. I don't care who tries to get in my way, if I feel auras coming on, I go home and lay down. I've got about a half hour to get somewhere dark and lay down and there isn't a force on this planet that could stop me.

Caffeine helps me get out faster, and emergency sumatriptan has worked well as well, but increases my risk of stroke, so it's truly emergency use only for me.

18.author: thatsalotofcats
18.body:
I’m too scared to take the sumatriptan (or anything else) so I just suffer with it. Get in my bed and bundle myself up with cozy blankets and try to sleep. The auditory hallucinations are bad sometimes though. 
I remember the one I had June 1st after I’d been watching Stranger Things…parts of the running up that hill song were literally swirling around inside my head for a day and a half. And had some pretty bad nightmares that night too (never had them about ST before and I’ve watched it too many time to count lol). 
Brains are weird sometimes.

18.author: jimmy9800
18.body: For sure. Sumatriptan is definitely a case-by-case drug. I know I'm not ok to drive after I take it. You might look into Goody's extra strength headache powder. It works well for me once I just have the headache. It makes it go and stay away for me. I don't know if I'm jealous of your auras or thankful! Mine are pure noise or lack of sense. The visuals are the weirdest. It's like that pre-sleep dream pattern thing but I can't get out of it. I am aware if motion happens but I can't see it. The audio auras are just like someone put a really good earmuffs over my left ear, or I have a real bad ear infection. Muffled and ringy. The body aura is exactly like a stroke. No feeling and a lack of control of the whole left side of my body, along with vertigo and nausea. It usually goes visual, left hand, left face, hearing, then full on left body. If it gets that far, I'm stuck like that for a couple days, but my vision does come back in a few hours.

18.author: thatsalotofcats
18.body:
This is so crazy to be talking about with someone else who actually gets what I’m talking about! I don’t know anyone else in real life who has these types of migraines so this is different! 
My ears also ring too; I have everyday ringing in my ears at all times, but the ringing gets so much worse with migraine. And your symptoms sound exactly like mine! Aura in my left eye, weakness and tingly/numb on left side up my arm and into my face. Weakness in both hands tho, because when I try to write down what time my symptoms start or whatever, my right hand feels all heavy and fuzzy. I’ve only ever lost vision on the left side tho; it’s like a hole or something, I can’t see my phone or anything it’s just a black spot for a bit.

18.author: jimmy9800
18.body: I'm thoroughly enjoying this! I've never met anyone with this before either! It's bizarre. It's like describing to someone how it feels to have your brain, fully conscious, slowly disconnect itself from all its inputs and then slowly figure itself out again. I get that black hole too! Although I'd describe it as more of a missing section of vision. I wouldn't know what color it is. I can't tell. It's like my brain is just making up whatever goes there and none of it could even be remotely real. The only thing about that hole that seems to be consistent is the edges shimmer, pulse, and almost seem brighter than they should be. It's always the first thing to show up for me, and it always initially looks like that spot that shows up when you look at a bright light and then look away, but instead of fading, it just grows and grows.

18.author: thatsalotofcats
18.body: Yep! It’s like looking at a bright light and then suddenly shutting it off and the spot is there. Also get rainbow shimmering colors that sort of go in a triangle shape. Always been scared it’ll happen when I’m driving or something but so far I’ve always been at home, so that’s good.

22.author: Comicspedia
22.body:
It's pretty simple - is your mind and body focused on one task until completion, or does your thinking or behavior turn toward progressing in a separate task at the expense of continuing same-skill progress in the first task? Sure, I can take out the garbage, chew gum, and carry on a conversation at the same time, but those require three distinctly different channels of processing (and complexity) that makes it easy to feel like everything is getting done to the same quality as one thing at a time. However, the touch and taste sensation of the gum will be reduced, garbage bag movement will show brief moments of uncoordinated movements, and speech patterns will slightly adjust. Sure, the three jobs get done "simultaneously" but not to the same quality as one thing at a time.

What happens when you sing along to a song you like that's playing while writing/typing out a recipe (ingredients AND directions) from memory? If we recorded you just singing the song, then just writing the recipe, and then trying to do both and compared penmanship and vocal qualities, we would *necessarily* find lower quality output in the multitasking video. In the wise words of Ron Swanson: "Never half-ass two things, whole-ass one thing."

Or you can look at gaming as a great example, the biggest myth creator of multitasking. I could write something extensive on that with examples, but perhaps the above example can suffice in demonstrating the limitations of our attention, memory, and cognitive processing when presented with multiple tasks.

22.author: Plantarbre
22.body:
So, strict parallelism of focus between two distincts tasks.

Be careful with multitasking in gaming. There absolutely is multitasking, but the mathematical modelization is different to what you have in mind. Tasks don't necessarily requires focus all the way to completion, so you can effectively have multitasking, but not multi-focus on the same unit of time. It's closer to a job scheduling problem.

22.author: Comicspedia
22.body:
I wouldn't describe it as you did, I'd use a more cognitive psych description wherein the brain determines a goal state and pursues perceptual patterns provided by internal or external stimuli that guide its behavioral actions toward that state. The brain recognizes when patterns emerge that do not align with the projected path or the goal state itself and, ideally, corrects its course to progress toward the goal state. 

When a pattern emerges that the brain follows, the original path is left and progress either halts or is stressed by the diverging paths. We call that being distracted, aka moving from the primary track that leads to the goal state.

28.author: fox-mcleod
28.body:
> If the brain is just a computer, then where is its program,

The brain is a neural network. It’s program is instantiated in the structure of neural connections. 


> and who wrote the program? 

Evolution. Much like the neural networks we create, the brain’s neural network was created through alternating variation and selection. Specific brains learn as they go like a specific instance of alpha go. The overall model was trained via the natural process of variation and selection over the hundreds of millions of years eukaryotes have lived and bred and died. It’s the same as like asking “if DNA is instructions to build an eye, who wrote the instructions?”


> I think we can know the brain is really nothing like a computer.

Moreover, the claim is not that the brain is like a computer at all. 

The claim is that there is nothing about the brain that a computer cannot simulate. 

Computers can simulate atoms. The brain is made of nothing but atoms. Therefore, a computer can in principle simulate a brain — true or false?

There are a few more ways we can say this:

1. Atoms are finite state machines and brains are just nodal networks of these FSMs. Computers can make both FSMs and nodal networks. 
1. Brains are Turing machines (given sufficient memory). Anything any Turing machine can compute and other turning machine can compute. Computers are turning machines. 
1. Anything that can be explained can be modeled. Brains are not inexplicable magic, therefore they can be modeled. Computers can run models.

You cannot just assume the answer as you have. 

Turing machines also do not exist. At least none have been created so far.

And no, it is not that case that anything that can be explained can be modeled, especially if the explanation is not persuasive. 28.author: AnchorKlanker
28.body:
I knew it. You have mistaken a model for the terrain, if you actually believe that atoms exist. Since you are a physicist, I'm confident that you know about subatomic particles and quantum theory, right? 

A computer cannot do anything except what it is told to do by a program. Do you accept that? Sufficiently large storage does not enable a computer to have the will to do anything. Sufficiently large and fast storage is most certainly a useful attribute of a computer, but that attribute does not even remotely resemble a brain. Brains, by the way, do not have particularly large accessible storage for most people, and they certainly do not have incredibly fast calculation speed. 

A brain can formulate analogies, recognize similes, concoct hypotheses, speculate, change its mind, compose a fanciful story, and exercise will. A computer can simulate facsimiles of some of these. But not in a way that a smart brain cannot discern.

Yes, AI is getting more and more advanced, but a Turing machine does not yet exist. I encourage you to research the term Turing machine. It does not mean computer.

Science is really good at exploring what "is" and describing "what happened." Science cannot and does not explain free will and human choice, because both go beyond what "is" and "what happened."  

Unless I misinterpreted your remarks, you did indeed claim that evolution must be able to explain consciousness, since you evidently accept the proposition that all can and must be explained by evolution.

I have made no claims whatsoever for magic or for creationism. I have made claims about human ignorance, which is clearly super abundant. 

I do not mean this to be offensive, but it appears to me that you do not understand what science is, if you do not see that the theory of natural selection is not falsifiable. 

This is my last post on this thread, as I have work to do, interesting as this conversation has been. 😊

37.author: SaintUlvemann
37.body:
***No. They are not all*** slacking at their job.

We know *so much* about the *objective differences* between the functioning of the different states' legislatures, that we can demonstrate that, for example, legislatures that are mostly not in session (aka, unprofessional legislatures), are [less responsive to citizens' concerns](https://www.jstor.org/stable/440439#metadata_info_tab_contents) in the sense that there's a greater mismatch between where public opinion in the state falls on the political spectrum, and the policies that that state's government enacts. 

>Legislatures that attract a high proportion of ambitious members and allow them to devote full-time effort to legislative work are the most responsive, collectively.

If all 50 states had legislatures that were slacking at their job, they would all have very loose connections between public opinion and state policy. 

Instead, some people get to live in states where the public policy actually matches public opinion. Those states' politicians are *demonstrably* doing their job.

38.author: srentiln
38.body: Normal by whose standards?  Children not having a hand in the work is a relatively new thing, and would be abnormal for much of human history world-wide.  By their standards, they already have a normal childhood, but they definitely should have a better one.

38.author: Daniel_The_Thinker
38.body: No not really, children have always had chores but that is very different from plantation work.

38.author: srentiln
38.body:
Agricultural "chores" are very much applicable to plantation work (granted, the labor of a medieval farm was divided up by age group).  Apprenticeships for skilled trades usually began around age 12, but could start as early as 7 years old with no pay (food, clorhing, and lodging provided instead) and full obedience demanded.  During the industrial revolution, child labor was used for the smaller hands being able to do things adult hands couldn't (as well as various other, often more despicable reasons).  Children were used as mining labor for years because they are smaller and therefore could fit into tighter spaces.

These are just the ones I know of without any specialized education in industrial history.  Their conditions were often horrid by our standards, but for them it was their "normal".

38.author: Daniel_The_Thinker
38.body:
No, there is a massive difference between a family farm and plantation work.

One you can have a kid just sitting in a field making sure the sheep don't get stuck in bushes and the other is where you can be continuously importing workers because grown men drop dead from the labor.

And the children working in factories was a contentious issue even in it's time.

Anyways an apprenticeship was an educational opportunity, why would an early 19th century village be having its children learn calculus?

38.author: srentiln
38.body:
You are speaking of a different farm and likely time period than I am.  Fields needed working long before our modern ideals and technology.  All members of the family had roles in the fields, whether it be using a scythe to harvest grains, or ensuring the harvested material is properly layer out for the techniques of processing and storage. Again, labor was their normal.

I never argued an apprenticeship wasn't educational, but unlike modern education where you learn by theory with little risk, they learned through practical application where even a small mistake could be life altering.  That was their normal.

The only things I have been presenting are the concept that "normal" isn't a universal thing, and that children shouldn't be a source of labor is a more modern concept.  To say they should have a normal childhood is equivalent to saying they should have the status quo instead of they should have better.

43.author: manfromthedesert
43.body:
According the the article other Bmod includes the host weaving a special web the benefits the wasp larvae or building special hatching crypts and then plugging the entrance with its head until they eat their way out. (by eating the head).  Wow. Yikes!
" Ichneumonid wasps from the Polysphincta genus group in the subfamily Pimplinae cause their spider hosts to create unusual web that are shaped to the benefit of the parasitoid and the species involved have been the subject of consistent research efforts (reviewed in [33,35,36]). Bassettia pallida—a cynipid oak gall wasp which alters the host oaks’ morphology to provide small chambers, or crypts, in which the larvae develop—is itself victim to attack by Euderus set, a eulophid wasp [36]. Normally, B. pallida will bore holes from the crypt to the surface of the oak and fly away, but, when parasitized by E. set, they stay in the hole they bore and plug the entrance with their heads [37]. This maintains the crypt as a protected space for the E. set larvae to continue to feed on the body of B. pallida, but also allows them to escape when they are matured, since E. set can only bore their way out of a crypt with difficulty."
